name: Kepler-80
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-80 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-80 is a star with 0.73 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.68 times its radius. It is located 1164.38 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 2 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-80 is known to have 6 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-80 b

Kepler-80 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2013-10. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.05 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-80.

The mass of Kepler-80 b is 6.93 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-80 b is 2.67 that of Earth. At 6.93 Earth masses, Kepler-80 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-80 c

Kepler-80 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2013-10. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 9.52 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-80.

The mass of Kepler-80 c is 6.74 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-80 c is 2.74 that of Earth. At 6.74 Earth masses, Kepler-80 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-80, which contains 6 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
